repnme.cdata!: Yemen - Groundwater and Soil Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Groundwater and Soil
            Conservation Project (GSCP) for Yemen were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was substantial; Bank performance was satisfactory
            and borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: the project was designed on the assumption
            that reducing extraction of water from an aquifer and
            reducing losses between the pump and the crop will make more
            water available for other uses. The main weakness of project
            design was that the project's main instrument governing
            water extraction (the tripartite agreement) was a contract
            with individual farmers while the regulation of extraction
            needed to be broadened to encompass the entire population of
            stakeholders using the groundwater aquifer. The
            implementation of small works by the communities through
            'community contracts' was found to be a great
            success in terms of quality of works and creation of the
            sense of ownership by the communities involved. The GSCP has
            helped develop and demonstrate institutional and technical
            methods that can help slow aquifer depletion, but for areas
            where affordable groundwater stocks are being exhausted,
            assistance should also be provided to help farmers cope with
            the transition to non-irrigated livelihoods.

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Groundwater and Soil Conservation
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Groundwater and
            Soil Conservation Project for Yemen are: to improve water
            use efficiency and increase farmers return to water through
            ad option of water saving technologies; and  increase
            surface and groundwater availability through rehabilitation
            of small to medium spate irrigation schemes, terrace
            rehabilitation, bank protection works and other water and
            soil conservation activities. The Implementation of the
            Groundwater and Soil Conservation Project (GSCP) had been
            carried out satisfactorily and its Implementation Status and
            Results (ISR) ratings for both the progress towards
            achieving Project Development Objectives (PDO) and
            Implementation Progress (IP) had been
            'satisfactory' until its IP rating was downgraded
            in June 2011 due to stoppage of most of the activities as a
            result of the current political and security environment in
            the country. A number of contracts (works and goods)
            amounting to US$6.6 million are put on hold now. Without
            completing these ongoing activities, the PDO may not be
            fully attained. The extension is thus necessary to complete
            the remaining contracts and attain the PDO. These contracts
            have already been awarded and are expected to be completed
            as soon as the current situation stabilizes.

display_title.display_title:
Yemen - Groundwater and Soil
            Conservation Project : restructuring : Main report
